thread.title: Giants Thwart Bills, Rex Ryan
thread.title_full: Giants Thwart Bills, Rex Ryan - WSJ

author: Stu Woo
title: Giants Thwart Bills, Rex Ryan
text:
0 COMMENTS ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.—Ralph Wilson Stadium wasn’t the ideal venue for the Giants to revive their season. Buffalo Bills fans are famously loud, and their team was 2-1 entering Sunday’s game, swaggering with an exciting quarterback, Tyrod Taylor, and the bully of a defense Rex Ryan said he’d build when he became head coach in January.
But as the game kicked off, a lone Giants fan sitting among the Bills faithful in the upper deck didn’t worry.
“We’re due for a Rex Ryan Special,” said 37-year-old Matt Charchan.
A Rex Ryan Special is a perfectly winnable game that Ryan’s squad blows because of a deluge of penalties and curious decisions, and a Rex Ryan Special is what went down in suburban Buffalo Sunday.
The Giants upset the Bills, 24-10, with their best defensive showing of the season and with help from Buffalo’s 17 penalties and befuddling third-down play calling, the kind of performance that marred Ryan’s chaotic six-season tenure with the New York Jets that ended with his firing last year.
Despite the ominous off-season that sidelined defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul and left tackle Will Beatty—and despite yet another clock-management blunder in the fourth quarter’s final minutes—the Giants are 2-2. Astonishingly, this puts them in position to take control of the chaotic NFC East division because of injuries and mismanagement in Dallas, Philadelphia and Washington.
“I don’t know if we’ve climbed out of the hole, but I know right now the Giants are relevant,” running back Andre Williams said.
Even on a cloudy, football-perfect autumn afternoon, Ralph Wilson Stadium is tough on visiting teams. Fans holler at opposing offenses on all four downs as if it were a college game. “It’s not like the Meadowlands,” said Charchan, who works in executive recruiting in Manhattan. “There’s not that enthusiasm on first and second down.”
The Bills fans hollered throughout the first quarter, as Giants took a 9-3 lead after quarterback Eli Manning found Dwayne Harris, the kick returner who has become the team’s No. 3 receiver, for a 21-yard touchdown pass. But when the Giants upped the advantage to 16-3 after Manning hit Rueben Randle for an 11-yard score, the crowd got restless.
ENLARGE The view from Ralph Wilson Stadium. Photo: Stu Woo Bills fans were mad their vaunted linemen weren’t getting close to Manning, who would get sacked only once in the game. “You might as well give Eli a pedicure while he’s back there,” said Marty Polowy, a longtime Bills season-ticket holder who invited Charchan to the game.
They were mad that the team continued to run the ball even though the Giants defense, led by defensive end Kerry Wynn’s eight tackles, had been stuffing the run and would eventually surrender only 55 rushing yards all game.
And they were mad that on third-and-long, Taylor consistently threw to receivers short of the first-down marker.
“It’s kind of puzzling,” said Polowy, a 37-year-old lawyer. “When you need eight (yards), why would you throw for six?”
The Bills didn’t cut into the lead until the fourth quarter, when Taylor threw a 23-yard touchdown to Karlos Williams to make the score 16-10. But on third down on the ensuing drive, the Bills blitzed and Manning got the ball quickly to running back Rashad Jennings, who dodged three defenders as he raced down the left sideline for a 51-yard touchdown.
With the Giants ahead 24-10, they could have clinched the game if not for another befuddling fourth-quarter decision.
With four minutes left and the ball at the Buffalo 8, Manning threw twice. The first was incomplete to Odell Beckham Jr. in the end zone. The second was intercepted by Buffalo’s Stephon Gilmore and returned to the Giants’ 30-yard line.
“Those Giants a——s,” shouted Bills fan Kristin Fyda. “Don’t be greedy!”
This time, the decision to throw instead of run didn’t cost the Giants.
With the help of a chop-block penalty that negated Taylor’s 32-yard touchdown pass, the Bills turned the ball over on downs, letting the Giants kneel to escape Buffalo with the upset victory.
“But did you see how hard the Giants were trying to give it away?” Charchan said. “Why were they passing?”
